instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chime but no video.
threads.message: Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B that came in w/ liquid damage originally. Have it up now but only chimes w/ no video (external or internal). Any help w/ this would be awesome. Thank you in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chime but no video.
threads.message:
Is <SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> present at <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>?

Where was the liquid damage?

What voltage is present on L9004/L9008?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chime but no video.
threads.message: All have voltage, backlit is present but no video. L9004/L9008 have 3.3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chime but no video.
threads.message: Board went through ultrasonic prior to getting to me. Kind of hard to tell to be honest where most of the damage was at.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chime but no video.
threads.message:
Wait is this one of those LP133WX2-TLGV screens being used here? They do that until you boot into an OS.

Try an original screen like LP133WX3-TLA* or LTN133AT09

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Chime but no video.
threads.message: Test all LVDS lines on diode mode at the LCD connector, positive to GND. Missing L9080 is a common problem. This is of course when you already tested a known good LCD assembly.
